🎯 Key Takeaways for quick navigation:  01:43 📏 Dot product helps find lengths and angles between vectors; cosine of the angle is the dot product divided by the product of vector lengths. 02:23 🧐 Vectors are perpendicular if their dot product equals zero. 04:41 🎯 Finding the component of a vector along a unit vector is done using the dot product. 06:58 🏞️ Components of vectors help analyze physical phenomena, like pendulum motion, breakingdown forces into tangent and normal components. 10:07 📐 Determinants help compute the area of shapes, with triangles as the building blocks for more complex figures. 18:27 📊 Determinant of two vectors in the plane is the area of the parallelogram formed by those vectors. 25:02 📦 Determinants extend to three vectors in space, providing a way to calculate volumes; the formula involves sub-determinants and follows a specific pattern. 29:44 📏 The determinant of three vectors (a, b, c) in space is geometrically related to the volume of the parallelepiped formed by these vectors. 33:32 🔄 The cross product is a vector operation specific to three-dimensional space, resulting in a vector. It's distinct from the dot product, which yields a scalar. 35:41 🤔 The cross product formula involves a symbolic determinant with unit vectors i, j, k. The actual calculation expands to three terms corresponding to each unit vector. 37:03 📏 The length of the cross product vector represents the area of the parallelogram formed by vectors a and b in space. 38:09 🔄 The direction of the cross product vector is perpendicular to the plane formed by vectors a and b. The right-hand rule determines whether it points upward or downward. 48:29 📏 The volume of a parallelepiped formed by vectors a, b, and c can be calculated using the triple product, where the determinant of ABC is equal to the dot product of a with the cross product of b and c.  Made with HARPA AI

28:38 "Why is the negative there?" Only the 2nd term has a negative sign, because only this term was constructed in a different manner than the 1st and 3rd terms. For ease and convenience, he constructed its 2 x 2 matrix using the column to its left and then the column to its right. However, the 1st and 3rd terms were constructed differently, using the column to their right, and then the column farther to their right. In the case of the 3rd term, there are no columns to its right, so you must "wrap around" the world, similar to the carriage return of a typewriter.  When you construct the 2nd term's 2 x 2 matrix using the "wrap around" method, a plus sign is used instead of a minus sign.

45:02 note to the viewers: basically you have to take the î and the j, or any number of fundamental vectors of any dimension, you should arrange the vectors inside a matrix in a way that a tiny identity matrix pops up, (for me that a more intuitive rule than this whole right hand thing)

I don't know if you've already found out the answer, but for any vector, its magnitude is the square root of the sum of of each one of its components, individually squared. For vector A-> = 2i-3j+7k, its magnitude is ||A|| = [(2)^2+(-3)^2+(7)^2]^(1/2) = [4+9+49]^(1/2) = [62]^(1/2) = 7.874... A vector's magnitude tells you how long the entire vector is, and the magnitude of a pair of vectors', multiplied by the cosine of the angle between them is equal to their dot product.  A vector's determinant tells you the area of the parallelepiped formed by the vector's cross product. In summary: Magnitude - length Determinant - area  Note: Determinants can be calculated for any square matrix (that is to say, any system of linear equations that has the same number of equations as variables), but a cross product can only be calculated for 1 dimension, 3 dimension, or 6 dimension vectors.

Also the method to find what is  ad-bc in 3x3 matrix or 3 vectors are quite intuitive .. That is delete the other elements for each row and column where the current element that are currently selected.. Let say first select 'a' then how to find 'd' is by deleting other elements that is on the same row and column as 'a' You do that for a1,a2,and a3 don't forget the minus .. Then add

28:50 -- The real answer to the question is that the negative there swaps the order of the vector columns. -a2 (b1c3-b3c1) = +a2 (b3c1-b1c3).  This is necessary because the way that the terms in the 3x3 matrix determinant are calculated actually requires you to horizontally scroll the matrix.  |a1 a2 a3| |b1 b2 b3|  -> a1 (b2c3-b3c2) |c1 c2 c3|  |a2 a3 a1| |b2 b3 b1|  -> a2 (b3c1-b1c3) |c2 c3 c1|  |a3 a1 a2| |b3 b1 b2|  -> a2 (b1c2-b2c1) |c3 c1 c2|  The reason why you have to horizontally scroll the matrix has to do with the noncommutativity of transformations. i.e. if you to rotate 90 degrees to the right and then rotate 90 degrees up; you'll be facing a completely different direction than if you rotated 90 degrees up and then 90 degrees to the right. Transformations have to be done in a very specific order: xyzxyz;  xy = -yx, zx = -xz, yz = -zy

The determinant computation formula that most of us know and make use of was originally proposed by Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz, who is also well known for being one of the two great fathers of Calculus, alongside Isaac Newton.  On another note, in most American high schools, determinants are rarely touched upon, and multivariable calculus is usually taken by American students along with linear algebra in third semester of university, which is why it's very likely that some students were first exposed to determinants in calculus before getting to see them in Linear Algebra. Some Linear Algebra textbooks, like Sheldon Axler's Linear Algebra Done Right, only introduce determinants and their computation methods after extensively covering much of what there is to say about vectors, eigenvectors, eigenvalues, and maps, spaces, and other more abstract parts of linear algebra. So it isn't exactly impossible for people to actually come off with the idea that determinants and vectors are actually part of calculus rather than linear algebra, by virtue of being introduced to them in the former course and only retaking the concepts in the latter course.

the pendulum was confusing for me

@electrophon  The reason he chooses a rotated coordinate system (i.e. normal/tangential, instead of vertical/horizontal), is because this allows the use of equations that explain the observed tangential motions of the pendulum. 1) The pendulum displays zero velocity and zero acceleration in the normal direction, if we assume that the string length is constant. Therefore the net force in the normal direction is zero. String tension is equal in magnitude but opposite in direction to the normal component of pendulum weight. 2) The pendulum displays oscillating harmonic motion in the tangential direction. It should be obvious that the only time the tangential force is zero, is when the pendulum passes through the equilibrium (lowest) position. At any position where the pendulum is displaced to the side, there will be a tangential component of the pendulum weight that accelerates the pendulum back towards the equilibrium position. In harmonic systems this is referred to as a "restoring force". 3) If we assume zero air resistance or friction, the harmonic system is undamped, and will continue to oscillate indefinitely. With damping, the amplitude of oscillation gradually decreases, unless power is somehow delivered to compensate for energy loss via damping. The hung weight in a typical grandfather clock stores enough energy for about a week.
In Physics, they use word Tension Force to give us Tension.  In Maths, he used Normal Force to make the situation Normal 😅

Not impressed so far. Prof. Auroux does not do a good job on explaining the details, e.g.: he explains that the dot product for 2 vectors <x,y,z>*<a,b,c> = a*x + b*y + c*z, but does not explain that the orthogonal components that are multiplied in this dot product result in zero. The dot product <x,y,z>*<a,b,c>  is actually  a*x*cos(0) + b*x*cos(90) + z*x*cos(90) + a*y*cos(90) + b*y*cos(0) + c*y*cos(90) + a*z*cos(90) + b*z*cos(90) + c*z*cos(0) = a*x + b*y + c*z  All too often math teachers jump over steps that they consider trivial, but these jumps can be rather confusing for the student! Combine this with students' lack of (ability for) disciplined thinking and/or having gotten lost at an early stage, and you have the reasons why so many people fail at math.

No matter how artificial and "strange" matrices look, they are always derived from very simple reasonings. In fact, you can quite easily derive the technicalities behind the determinant matrix operations, cofactor expansions etc simply by playing around with row reductions etc and experiment a bit. I managed to derive the cross product even before I read the definition behind it, because I love figuring things out like that.  One major advantage in knowing the theory behind these things is that you don't need to "look it up", because since you know how it works you can simply derive it on the spot.

ok.., number 1 my university is not as reputed as MIT, so just leave that, secondly the topics i have done so far are linear transformations and co-factor expansion and thirdly we can't even think of solving a 2x2 matrix we are bound to solve  a 4x4 and 5x5 matrix on normal bases.

Sorry to say it but those are not advanced topics. We covered linear transformations in my first year class at NYU and cofactor expansion is just a very simple method used to evaluate higher degree matrices. In fact if you knew anything about linear algebra you would know that cofactor expansion is used to get a higher degree matrix into a form that we are able to make the same calculations we use on 2x2 matrix on to find the determinant  [ex. +/- (Cofactor) x (det A), where det A is either ad-bc or a very similar repetitious computation]. Other methods make the calculations even simpler - ex. for triangular matrices you take the dot product of the main diagonal entries. Using row echelon also helps to find the determinant of large matrices but that's not advanced either. These methods are all shortcuts but have the same principles as the methods used to find the det of a 2x2 matrix. If you a learning these topics now then what have you been learning since grade 6? You seem very dishonest and clearly envious of MIT for some reason.

@phtotti It is quite possible you learned it in highschool... but more than likely a simplified version. Calculus theories like limits, derivatives, integrals...etc can be taught at a lower level math if you skip the details of the how and why. In college you need to learn those things that they left out so that you can move on in math.
